Important information

For equipable items, it's important that you understand that there are 2 types of meshes.

  • Static meshes which are bound to the character with the use of a 'socket' , we'll call these Socketed Items
  • Animated meshes which are a child of the character mesh , we'll call these Animated Items

For simplicity sake we'll just say that both types are equiped to a socket, this has nothing to do with which type it is.

Socketed Items

This is a simple mesh you created, only point of attention is that you must place it correctly on the origin(0,0,0) coordinate, where you want the character to hold it.

For a sword, the middle of the handle would be at 0,0,0

Sockets: head, left hand, right hand, back

Examples: hair, helmet, weapons, quiver, saddle(in case of a horse character), ...

Animated Items

These meshes need to be parented to a skeleton and given proper weights for each bone.

Sockets: chest, gloves, pants, boots

Examples: armor, tunic, leather boots, leggings, ...

Creating the mesh

A guideline for scale, in case you don't want to mess with scales, pay attention to it from the start. 1 blender unit = 1 meter

Some guidelines for polycount, it's a number to aim for. Don't worry if it's slightly over. Just make sure you don't have a ridiculous amount :) (Less triangles = faster = more fps) These are in triangles, so if you used quads in your mesh, you'll have to multiply with 2.

Armor 

Normal helmet     : ~500       
Full faced helmet : ~800/1000
A body armor      : ~1000

Weapons

A sword           : ~250
Detailed sword    : ~400
Small axe         : ~300
Two handed axe    : ~400
Two bladed axe    : ~500
Lance             : ~150/250
Spear             : ~200/300
Bow               : ~100/200
Crossbow          : ~300/400
Shield            : ~400/500

Enough with the guidelines already, let's start modeling!

Animated Items

Socketed Items

Getting it in-game

All items are referenced using an unique ID, togheter with other attributes they're collected in data/xml/items/items.xml.

Open this file in an text editor.

Understanding VFS

All paths in datafiles are VFS paths (Virtual File System) "/peragro/" actually points at "where ever peragro is installed/data"

Say your item is located at "/peragro/meshes/bogus.xml" it's real path would be "C:\Program Files\Peragro Tempus\data\meshes\bogus.xml"

Replacing an item

If you want to replace an existing item, search for it and locate the <file> tag this will tell you where the file is located, so you can replace it.

Also note the name in the <mesh> tag, you want to change your meshname in your exported library file to this.

Adding a new item

At the end add a new entry, make sure it has a unique ID. Best to copy an item that resembles your own, so you don't have the edit a lot.

It should look something like: 

<item>
	<id>4</id>
	<name>Flaming Dragon Edge Sword</name>
	<icon>set:Weapons image:DragonEdgeSword</icon>
	<description>
		Past on from generation to generation of Tibet Monks
		who mastered the movement of the Mighty Dragon
		and could swing this sword soo fast it would
		actually caught fire, inflicting extra damage on the foo.
	</description>
	<file>/peragro/meshes/bogus.xml</file>
	<mesh>foobar</mesh>
	<stackable>1</stackable>
	<weight>30</weight>
	<equiptype>bothhands</equiptype>
        <attrib>
          <type>sword2h</type>
	  <damage>
		<hp>10</hp>
	  </damage>
	  <requirements>
		<str>100</str>
	  </requirements>
        </attrib>
</item>
